title: 105_hr4464
content: The "Military Retiree Health Care Task Force Act of 1998" establishes the "Medicare Eligible Military Retiree Health Care Consensus Task Force" to fulfill specific duties. The Task Force is tasked with studying promises made to Uniformed Services members regarding health care coverage post-separation, sharing agreements between the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs for military retirees, and proposals for health care coverage for medicare eligible military retirees and their dependents. A report is due within one year of the Task Force's establishment. The Department of Defense Task Force must submit a report to Congress within one year of its establishment, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions based on studies conducted. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Task Force consists of 12 members appointed by various officials, including representatives of veterans service organizations, military associations, health care professionals, and officers or employees of the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Task Force consists of 12 members appointed by various officials, including representatives of veterans service organizations, military associations, health care professionals, and officers or employees of the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Secretary of Health and Human Services appoint members, with a limit of 6 members from the same political party. Members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and their term lasts for the life of the Task Force. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Members of the Task Force are appointed for the remainder of the term, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Appointments can be made without regard to certain regulations. Members can continue even if they no longer hold certain positions. They receive no additional pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses and per diem. The Task Force members are appointed for the remainder of the term, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. They receive reimbursement for expenses and per diem. Seven members constitute a quorum, and a chairperson is elected at the first meeting. Meetings are held at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members. SEC. 5. STAFF OF TASK FORCE AND SUPPORT SERVICES. The Task Force shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, paid at the minimum GS-15 rate. The Director can appoint up to eight staff members without following certain civil service laws regarding appointments and pay rates. Staff members cannot receive pay exceeding the minimum GS-13 rate. The Task Force's Director is paid at the minimum GS-15 rate and can appoint up to eight staff members. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Task Force on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 6. POWERS OF TASK FORCE. The Task Force has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain official data from government departments. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Task Force, and use the United States mails. Administrative support services can be requested by the Task Force. The Task Force, upon request, can receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. They also have the authority to contract with government and private agencies for supplies or services. The Task Force will terminate 90 days after submitting the report under section 3(b).
